p.seg: Whenever I consider what is made by persons of talent
there is something within me that lets me grasp their strenuous efforts (or "use of mind").
Though in the way they let loose their words and expel phrases
there are indeed many mutations,
still we can grasp and speak of value and beauty in them.
And whenever I myself compose a literary piece,
I perceive full well their state of mind (or "the situation).
I constantly fear failure in my conceptions not being equal to the things of the world,
and in my writings not being equal to my writings to being equal to my conceptions.
I suppose it is not the understanding that is difficult,
but rather the difficulty lies in being able to do it well.
Thus I write "A Poetic Exposition on Literature": first to transmit the splendid intricacy of craft of previous writers,
and second, therey to discuss the origins of success and failure in the act of writing.
I hope that at some time it will be known for minutely exhausting the subtleties of the subject.
When it comes to taking an ax in hand to chop an ax-handle
the model is not far from you;
however, it is hard indeed for language to follow the movements (mutations) of the hand.
What can be put into words
is all here.
He stands in the very center, observes in the darkness.
Nourishes feeling and intent in the ancient canons.
He moves along with the four seasons and sighs at their passing on,
Peers on all the things of the world, broods on their profusion,
Grieves for the falling leaves in strong autumn,
Rejoices in the pliant branches in sweet spring;
His mind shivers, taking the frost to heart;
His intent is remote, looking down on the clouds.
He sings the blazing splendor of moral power inherited by this age,
Chants of the pure fragrance (or "reputation") of predecessors,
Roams in the groves and treasure houses of literary works,
Admires the perfect balance of their intricate and lovely craft.
With strong feeling he puts aside the book and takes his writing brush
To make it manifest in literature.
Thus it begins:
retraction of vision, reversion of listining,
Absorbed in thought, seeking all around,
My essence galloping to the world's eight bounds,
My mind roaming ten thousand yards, up and down.
And when it is attained:
light gathers about moods and they grow in brightness,
Things become luminous and draw one another forward;
I quaff the word-hoard's spray of droplets,
And roll in my mouth the sweet moisture of the Classics;
I drift between Heaven and the abyss, at rest in the current,
I bathe in the falling stream, immersed it its waters;
Then, phrases from the depths emerge struggling
as when the swimming fish, hooks in their mouths, emerge from the bottom of the deepest pool;
and drifting intricacies of craft flutter down,
as when the winging bird, caught by stringed arrow, plummets from the tiered clouds.
He gathers in writing omitted by a hundred generations,
Picks rhymes neglected for a thousand years;
It falls away - that splendid flowring of dawn, already unfurled,
But there opens the unblown budding of evening.
He observes all past and present in a single moment,
touches all the world in the blink of an eye.
Only afterward he selects ideas, setting out categories
Tests phrases, putting them in their ranks,
Striking open all that contains light,
Plucking everything that embraces sound within.
He may rely on the branches to shake the leaves,
or follow the waves upstream to find the source;
He may trace what is hidden as the root and reach the manifest;
Or seek the simple and obtain the difficult.
It may be that the tiger shows its stripes and beasts are thrown into agitation,
Or a dragon may appear and birds fly off in waves around it.
It may be steady and sure, simply enacted,
or tortuously hard, no ease in it.
He empties the limpid mind, fixes his thoughts,
Fuses all his concerns together and makes words.
He cages Heaven and Earth in fixed shape,
Crushes all things beneath the brush's tip.
At first it hesitates on his dry lips,
But finally flows freely through the moist pen.
Natural principle supports the substance, a tree's trunk;
Pattern hangs down in the branches, a net of lushness.
Each mutation is right there on the face.
When thought fares through joy, there will surely be laughter;
When we spak of lament, sighs have already come.
He may have grasped the tablet and dashed it off lightly,
Truly mood and manner are never uncoordinate:
Or may have held the brush in his lips, [his mind] far in the distance.
In this event can be found joy,
Firmly held in honor by Sages and men of worth.
A trial of void and nothing to demand of it being,
A knock upon silence, seeking sound.
He contains remote distances on a sheet of writing silk,
Emits a boundless torrent from the speck of mind.
Language gives it breadth, expanding and expanding;
Thought pursues it, growing deeper and deeper.
It spreads the rich scent of drooping blossoms,
Produces the dark density of green twigs:
Sparkling, the breezes fly and whirling gusts commence;
Swelling, clouds rise from the forest of writing brushes.
There are ten thousand different normative forms,
The things of the world have no single measure:
jumbled and jostling, fleeting past
Their shapes are hard to describe.
Diction displays its talents in a contest of artfulness;
Concept holds the creditor's contract and is the craftsman.
There he strives between being and nothing,
In deep or shallow, not giving up.
Though it may depart from the geometry of circle and square,
He hopes to exhaust the limits of shape and countenance.
Thus to make a brave display for the eyes, prize extravagance;
To content the mind, value the apposite.
That the words run out is not impediment:
Discourse attains its ends only in broadening.
The poem follows from the affections and is sensuously intricate;
Poetic exposition gives the normative forms of things and is clear and bright;
Stele inscription unfurls pattern to match substance;
Threnody swells with pen-up sorrow;
Inscription is broad and concise, warm and gentle;
Admonition rrepresses, being clear and forceful;
Ode moves with a grand ease, being lush;
Essay treats essentials and fine points, lucidly and expansively;
Memorial to the throne is even and incisive, calm and dignified;
Persuasion is flashy, delusory and entrancing.
Though fine distinctions are being made in these,
They prohibit deviation and restrain impulsiveness.
Require that your words attain their ends, that the principle come forth;
Having nothing at all to do with long-winded excess.
As things, there are many postures;
As normative forms, there are frequent shiftings.
In forming conceptions, value clever craft;
In expelling words, honor the alluring.
When it comes to the alternation of sounds
They are like the five colors, setting each other off:
Though there is no constancy in their passing on or halting-
A rocky path, that cannot be made easy-
Still, if one grasps mutation and understand succession,
It is like opening a channel to receive a stream.
But if you miss the occasion and bring things together too late,
You will always have the beginning following the end.
Error in the relative positions of Purple [Heaven] and Brown [Earth],
Brings mere muddiness and no vididness.
At times you may transgress against a previous section,
Or trespass ahead to some later part.
At times your diction may be faulty, though the principle follows its proper course,
Or the language proceeds smoothly, though the idea is blocked.
Avoid both [these situations] and the beauty is doubled;
If the two occur together, twice the damage.
Consider relative merits by the tiniest measures;
Decide on rejecting or retaining by a hair's breadth:
If what has been trimmed to the most accurate measure
Truly follows the straight line, then it must be suitable.
It may be that the pattern is lush and the principle rich,
But in terms of concept, it does not really have a point.
Reaching its limit, there is no second significance;
EXhausted, it will be unable to increase.
Set a suggestive phrase in an essential spot
And it will be a riding crop for the whole piece:
Even though the word-hoard follows the statutes,
One must have this to compete for great merit.
The accomplishment will be great and the complications few.
So choose just what is enough and to not change it.
It may be that your intricately crafted thoughts cohere, finely patterned,
A lucid loveliness, gloriously bright,
Shimmering like a man-colored brocade,
Or deeply moving like a flurry of strings.
Then suppose you find what you aim at lack distinction -
Your work unwittingly corresponds to some long-ago piece.
Even if the shuttle and loom were in my own feelings,
I must dread lest others have preceded me;
If it damages integrity and transgresses what is right,
Though I begrudge doing so, I must cast it from me.
It may be that a blossom comes forth, a spike of grain stands upright,
separated from the crowd, isolated from the sense:
A shope no shadow can vollow,
A sound to which no echo can be linked.
It stands there towering, solitary and immobile,
Not woven in with the constant tones.
Mind is in a desolate expanse, nothing corresponds;
Conception circles aimlessly, unable to leave it.
The mountain shimmers when jade is in the stone,
The stream is alluring when its waters bear pearls;
Thorn bushes and medlars need not be cut down-
They, too, can become glorious by the roosting kingfisher.
If we link an art song with a popular tune,
We may augment what is exceptional.
Suppose you put your words in too short a rhyme;
They face the end of their tracks， a solitary s tirring.
They look down into a dismal stillness， lack companion;
They look up into vast space and continue nothing .
Compare it to a string of limited range， strung alone-
Within it lies clcar song， but nothing responds.
Suppose you entrust your lines to dreary tones :
The words will have pointless languor and want splendor;
A form constituted of lovely and ugly mixed，
Good substance encumbered by blemishes .
Likened to pipes in thc lower part of the hall played too fast-
Though there is response， there is no harmony.
Suppose you disregard natural principle and keep what is strange，
Pointless quest for the empty， pursuit of the over-subtle:
The words will lack feeling， be short on love，
Your lines will drift aimlessly to no end .
As when the strings arc too thin and the bridges set too tight ，
There may be harmony ， but no strong emotion
But suppose you let yourself go rushing into choral unisons，
Devote yourself to the bewitching bcauty of an orgy of sound:
Pointlessly you please the eye， match the common taste，
The sound rnay be loud indeed， but the tune inferior .
Be awarc of Fang-lu and Sangjian一
Though strong cmotion is present， it may lack dignity .
Supposc you have a chaste indifference and graceful restraint，
Always cutting away complexity， getting rid of excess:
It will lack that "flavor omitted" of the ceremonial broth;
It will be the same as the chaste reverberations of a temple zither.
Even though “ one sings and thrice join in harmony， "
Dignity you may have， but no allure.
In thc way it is cut， cither terse or elaborated，
ln form， descending or ascending :
One moves into mutations according to what is appropriate，
And the fìne turns have the most subtle moods .
Sometimes the language is artless ， but the lesson artful;
Sometimes the principle is plain， and the diction light;
Sometimcs following what is old yields something very new;
Sometimes moving with murkiness gives renewed clarity;
Sometìmes a glancing overview brings requisite insight;
Somctimes rhe essence follows only after laborious honing.
Liken it to the dancer， flinging her sleeves to the rhythm，
Or to the singer， sending out her voice in response to the strings .
It is this that Wheclwright Bian coule not put into words，
Nor is even the most glittering discourse able to catch its essence.
The overall statutes of phrasing and writing's regulations
Are things to which my heart has submitted.
I have a fine sense of the constant transgressions in the disposition of this age，
And recognize what is pure in former worthies .
Although something may emerge from the depth of the artful mind，
It may still be ridiculed in the eyes of the artless .
Such agate flourishes and filigree of jade
Are like thc wild beans on the ccntral plain，
Never exhausted， like the Great Bellows，
All nurtured together with Heaven and Earth
Yet however abundant they are in this age，
I sigh that thcy do not fill my open hand .
My misfortune is to have a pint-sized capacity, often empty，
And I suffer at the difficulty of continuing the apt words of the past.
So I limp along in rhymes too short，
Give forth ordinary tones to complete my songs，
And always some regret remains at the end of a piece-
Never is my heart full ， never am I satisfied.
I am frightened that this vessel will be tapped as it lies in the dust，
And will surely be laughed at by te ringing jade.
At the conjunciton of stirring and response,
At the demarcation between blockage and passage,
What comes cannot be halted,
What goes off cannot be stopped.
When it hides, it is like a shadow disappearing,
When it moves, it is like an echo rising.
When Heaven's motive impulses move swiftly on the best course,
What confusion is there that cannot be put in order?
Winds of thought rise in the breast,
A stream of words flows through lips and teeth.
Burgeoning in tumultuous succession,
Something only the writing brush and silk can imitate.
Writing gleams, overflows the eyes:
The tones splash on, filling the ears.
But when the six affections are stalled and hampered,
When mind strains toward something, but spirit remains unmoved,
One is immobile as a bare, leafless tree,
Gaping empty like a dried-up stream.
One draws the soul to search secres recesses,
Gathers vital forces to seek from oneself;
But natural principle is hidden and sinks away ever farther,
Thought struggles to emerge, as if dragged.
Thus at times I wear out my feelings, and much is regretted;
At other times I follow the bent of my thoughts with few transgressions.
It is not within the scope of my concertrated forces.
At times I consider the emptiness in my heart and turn against myself,
That I do not know the means to open this blockage.
The functioning of literature lies in being
The means for all natural principle.
It spreads across ten thousand leagues, nothing bars it;
It passes through a million years, a ford across.
Looking ahead, it grants models to coming genrations;
Looking back, it contemplates images in the ancients.
It succors the Way of the ancient kings, on the point of falling;
It manifests reputation, does not let it be lost.
No path lies so far in cannot be integrated;
No principle so subtle it cannot be woven in.
Peer of clouds and rain with their fertile moisture,
Semblance of divinity in transformation.
When it covers metal and stone, virute is spread;
Flowing through strings and flutes, it is daily renewed.
Although this thing is in the self,
